The Cabinet considered, as a matter of urgency, the undertaking given by the Prime minister in Parliament on September 16th to consider variouscases in which particular classes of persons had been represented to be unfairly affected by the proposedcuts .The First Lord of the Admiralty, the secretaries of State for War and Air, the Home Secretary, andthe President of the Board of Education reported theresults of enquiries which had already been made intothe incidence of the cuts in the services for whichthey were respectively responsible.On a full review of all the circumstances theCabinet agreed (a) That arrangements should be made forthe following Private Notice question to be addressed to the Prime minister the same afternoonr-"To ask the Prime Minister whether he is now in a position to make astatement in regard to the classesof persons involved by economieswhose cases are of peculiarly greathardship",and that the Prime Minister's reply shotildbe as follows'The Government has, as announced byme on Wednesday last, been examiningdetails of the proposed scheme of reductions.
